lines.text: What kind of car is that?
Crosley!
And that one?
Nash!
Pret-ty good!
I don't want you to leave!
One way or the other,we all have to leave.
Vy didja cud da TOIKEY?

[Voice of off-screen doctor as he attends to Michael]
He's not allergic to bees, so there's no real problem. He's just going to be uncomfortable for a while.
I hate the suburbs!
In the old days, if you had to pee, you peed on a tree - with no "may" or "can". That's progress.
If I knew things would no longer be, I would have tried to remember better.
[first lines]

I came to America in 1914 - by way of Philadelphia. That's where I got off the boat. And then I came to Baltimore. It was the most beautiful place you ever seen in your life. There were lights everywhere! What lights they had! It was a celebration of lights! I thought they were for me, Sam, who was in America. Sam was in America! I didn't know what holiday it was, but there were lights. And I walked under them. The sky exploded, people cheered, there were fireworks! What a welcome it was, what a welcome!
Who said names were supposed to be easy to say? What are you, a candy bar?
He wets the bed. My dad wets the bed.
[repeated line]
I came to America in 1914...

[regarding the family's move out of the city]
I never even heard of the suburbs until this thing happened.
Jules, if you stop remembering, you forget.

[Meeting the train that carries her brother]
Where are the people who know where the people are?
